content.description: There is a low crux  and a higher one that involves following a left leaning weakness.
content.protection: 8 bolts and steel biner lower offs.
content.location: Starts just left of a small oak turns a bulge then easy ground leads to a right angling weakness that gets exited left at

content.description: This is the second climb from the left. It cruises up on good rock just to the right of the large flake. An awesome first lead as there is a bolt about every 8 Ft. No excuses here. Good for the grade.
content.protection: About 7 well placed bolts to chains on a nice ledge

content.description: "Climb steep rock just right of the big corner." - EFR. An unknown party added a 2-bolt anchor about 120 feet up this climb, but it's not a lower-off anchor, so you'll still have to continue climbing to the top of Barnum Rock, and then walk off. You'll probably have to turn it into at least 2 pitches.
content.protection: R-rated trad route. There aren't any bolts, except for a not-very-useful 2-bolt anchor about 120 feet up the route.
content.location: Right of the corner that "In the Pokey" goes up, and left of the layback crack that "Gumbercules" climbs. Since this is an R-rated route, it doesn't really follow a particular crack system.

content.description: This climb follows the obvious line on the semi-detached flake. A little thin at the start then big jugs and positive holds on the upper section.
content.protection: This route has been bolted since the guide was published. It's printed as 5.9- but it's definitely easier now. 5 bolts to 2 bolt chain anchor.

content.description: This climb is really fun and fairly sustained and like all of the routes at this crag big holds abound, The best thing is that after the first half the climb steepens and getting to the anchor might be the crux. Fortunately a great jug allows you to easily clip the anchor. This route is Rachel's one and only first ascent and she did a ton of the work instead of just waltzing in and grabbing the glory. So cool how engaged you were Rachel.
content.protection: 7 bolts and Steel biner lower offs.
content.location: Starts just left of Tough Gumby.

content.description:
Walk-off required

 A fun, but run-out adventure climb. You should be very comfortable at this grade. After the first pitch, which is probably 200-220 feet by itself, another hundred feet of 3rd/4th class scrambling will take you to the top of Barnum Rock. Walk off back to the base. The route goes into the shade in the late afternoon.

 If you have a 70m rope and sling everything long, you'll just barely be able to make it to the 2-bolt anchor, which is about 15 meters above a small pine tree growing out of the rock. If you can't make that, there are some (but not many) options for a gear anchor lower down.
content.protection: Overall, there aren't a lot of options for pro. Plan to go 20 or 30 feet between placements. I used nuts and cams up to #3 Camalot. If you like tricams, you'll find places to use them. Higher up, there are some plates that will remind you of Rappel Rock or Cochise. There is a 2-bolt anchor at the top of the pitch (which is easy to miss), and then it's another 100 feet of 3rd/4th-class to the top of Barnum Rock, which you can either un-rope and solo (it's pretty casual), or stay roped up and belay off of gear at the top, and then walk off to the north.
content.location: You pass by it on the way to Gumby Wall proper. It's on the east face, before you scramble up the gully to access Gumbuttress and everything to the left of it.

climbs.name: The Gumby Sanction
climbs.fa: Scott McNamara, Kevin Carmichael, Eric Fazio-Rhicard

content.description: One of the better route names on the mountain.  Fun easy route, decent exposure on the buttress.  A little runout in the middle, but really easy climbing.  Shares anchors with Gumbuttress.
content.location: 3rd climb from left on main wall.

content.description: Starts on a section of a exfoliating well protected slab and leads up to a bulge with knobs and edges. Follow the bolt line up slabs to a final steep section.
content.location: This is about 30 feet right of Gumbercules.

climbs.name: Gumbuttress
climbs.fa: Scott McNamara, Kevin Carmichael, Eric Fazio-Rhicard

content.description: Goes past big flake/chickenhead things (watch your rope) and up the wall right of The Gumby Sanction.  Upper wall looks like 5.9 until you get there.  Easier than it appears.  Shares chains with Gumby Sanction.

A mildly-moderate mid-mountain mixed-route multi-pitch. Morning sun and afternoon shade.Pitch 0: 25 feet. 4th-class slab with 1 bolt. Chain anchors. This anchor can be used for teaching people how to rappel, belay from the top, build/clean anchors, etc. Or link it with Pitch 1. Pitch 1: 100 feet. Clip a bolt and then climb up to a short, steep, layback crack. This is probably the crux of the route. Pull the crux and then follow a crack for about 30 feet. Then, start trending up and slightly left on chickenheads/plates until you reach a 2-bolt anchor. This anchor has lower-off biners, in case you want to stop here. You can lower to the top of P0 (where most climbers would feel comfortable un-roping) with a 60m, or you can reach the bottom with a 70m. Tie knots in your rope ends!Pitch 2: 80 feet. From the P1 anchor, traverse about 8 feet to the right (past the corner), and then climb up and slightly right on plates. You can get some small cams and nuts in cracks or between plates. When it gets steep, you'll encounter the first of 3 bolts. Climb past the bolts and belay at a 2-bolt anchor on a really big ledge. Or you can make an anchor on tricky gear about 10 feet to the left of the 2-bolt anchor, but you'll probably want to eventually transfer the belay to near the bolted anchor for P3 anyway. Pitch 3: 100 feet. From the 2-bolt anchor, climb up and to the right, past 3 bolts, and then scramble up whatever path you want until the climb levels out. Find something natural to belay off of. There are plenty of options. It's still another 80 feet to the true summit, but most climbers would feel comfortable un-roping at this point and just hiking the rest.Scramble off the back of the formation, and then bushwhack down and east, back to where you started.
content.protection: A few bolts on sections that can't be protected with gear. A single rack up to #3 and nuts should be sufficient. Some small cams (like BD .2, .3) are useful on P2, but small nuts could suffice. Bolted anchors at the top of P1 and P2. You'll have to make a natural anchor at the top of P3.
content.location: This is on the east face of Barnum Rock. You hike past it before you arrive at Gumbuttress and the other routes commonly associated with Gumby Wall. It starts at the bottom-most portion of the slab.

climbs.name: Chumming for Gumbies
climbs.fa: Scott McNamara, Kevin Carmichael, Eric Fazio-Rhicard

content.description: Fun easy climb.  Goes up big outcropping of quartz, which makes for different climbing.
content.location: 2nd climb from left on main wall.

content.description: Start up a slightly decomposing slab until it is possible to turn a bulge to the left then follow the bolts to the same anchors. There are some longer runs between bolts on easier ground. Of course you could get hurt but one would have to be pretty drunk to fall off in those spots.
content.protection: 11 bolts to steel biner lower offs.
content.location: Six to eight feet right of Free University.

content.description: A sunny, exposed SW facing crag with very good quality rock. Good choice for a first time lead. Most routes are well bolted. There are occasional access issues with nesting peregrine falcons, but a call or email to the Coronado National Forest will give current info on possible closures - the wall is usually open even during the dates listed above.
